DEATH IN THE DYNAMO If the law i3 changed from hanging to death by electricity then it should and would bo made to include women as well as men. Any discrimination between the sexes would make the law unconstitutional." ""Would there b3 any objection to execut ing women with electricity.'" "No, sir; there would not. I think there would no longer be tho samo prejudico that thcro is now, because Imaging is a poor way of inflicting the death penalty." "How would you uso electricity?" "Just seo here," said Dr. Southwick, jumping up and .seating himself, in an arm chair. "Tho condemned man cansifc natur ally in a chair like this, placo his liands on the metal arms and converse with those around him. Tho metal plates would ba connected with a powerful d3namo and at tho proper moment somebody in another room would press a button, closo tho current and tho fatal shock would pass through tho body of the subject. Tho chargo would go straight through tho heart and lungs and penetrate the system, death instantly result ing.
Theso 'executions could take place in tho jail proper, in a room set apart for that purpose, with no appli ances save that of a chair, with tuo nana rest of each arm properly connected with an electric machine, in which tho condemned might bo seated and tho connection made by strapping a hand to the hand rest on each chair. There can bo no difficulty whatever in procuring a current of electricity of suffi cient strength to paralyze tho muscles of tho heart by this method. Indeed, tho cur rent that is used in this city for electric lighting purposes is of sufficient strength to absolutely dismember the body of nay human being, but a current of electricity of suffi cient strength to cause instantaneous death by passing from hand to hand through the heart wi'l not mark the body in tho least.

A PLAN PROPOSED murderers in New York sate will depart this life on a streak of light ing. The subject of putting murderers to death by electricity has been agitated in the Empire state for more than a year. After mature deliberation it was concluded that hanging would have to go. Hanging has been the fashionable mode of punishment for centuries, but a commission *appointed by Governor Hill concluded that it was too harrowing. They made a number of experiments, and finally decided upon electricity. A bill was passed by the legis lature, but-no provision was made as to the way the fluid was to be applied. Finally the Medico-legal society took the matter Uo, ap pointed a commission, and the result was that a particular form of applying the elec tricity was suggested.

No WORD OF REPENTANCE With Brute Courage Czolgosz Met De-th In the Electric Chair.
F. Czolgosz, alias Fred Nieman, was successfully electrocuted at Auburn prison this morning

ELECTRIC CHAIR GETS MEN WHO MURDERED ROSENTHAL After Becker's body had been removed from the electric chair, Samuel Haynes, a nefgro murderer, was brought into the execution room and electrocuted
Herman Rosenthal, the gambler for whose murder Charles Becker was sen tenced to die in the electric chair, was shot to death by hired gunmen in the early morning of July 16, 1912, in front of the Hotel Metropole on Forty-third street, a few stepB from Broadway.
Becker was sentenced six days later to die 1 the electric chair during the week of December 9, 1912

HOW IT FEEKS TO DIE IN THE ELECTRIC CHAIR WHKN the electric chair was sub stituted for the old fashioned gallows in New York it was be cause it was believed that electrocution was painless. But just what were the sensations of death in the electric chair scientists were unable to say, because no electrocuted victim came back to life to tell tliern.

DEANS OF DEATH WATCH the first electric execution arrived at the prison. New Tork State had just passed a law substituting the electric chair for the hangman's noose. There had never been an electric execution and everybody was prospecting as to who would be the first person electrocuted and'whether he would bo killed with out conscious suffering or tortured to death

TAMPA. Fla.. Aug. 4.—Approximately 15,000 Tampa dgar factory employes walked out on a general strike here this after noon as a protest against Governor Fuller’s decision to send Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti to the electric chair.

Now, while awaiting a call to th throne, he's xupjiorting hims« If by making ice crearn. It’s c hilling work, though not so chilling as the* thought that there may not be any throne t be called to. All he ran.do is hop: that the Ministry of Justice finally will reject the electric chair. Nor is he wholly without ground, for optimism. For, though Madam Guillotine is not pretty to watch (thL. seems to be the principal reason for the contemplated change-over, th French being sick of the sight c. blood French authorities believe sh gets her work done moie quickly thus humanely—than electricity. Moreover, in normal times, she hat the advantage of mobility. France long has had only two guil lotines, one of which irmainc*d in Paris while the other toured the provinces. Since electric chairs are less easily shipped around, it prob ably would he* necessary to get on for each department of the country a matter of 89 separate chairs ano consequently, of considerable expense. So, taken all in all, Andre Obrecht would seem to stand as good a chance of warming a now vacant throne a.* any of Europe’s other dispossess! heirs apparent. THE AMEIIM W W Hkl.’

MANNING, S. C.. Oct. 22.—Edmund Bigham, under sentence to the electric chair October 31 for the slaying of five members of his family, has been granted a temporary stay of execution. Big ham’s electrocution was automatically delaved 30 days when Judge Malcdlm Woods allowed defense attorneys that much time to file an appeal to the su preme court.

The Statue for IKevr York Harbor. A French paper eaya The colossal statue of "Liberty Lighting tho World, erected by France and Ameri ca in remembrance of their old friend ship, is coming ont little by little from the immense workshops established expressly for its construction in the Kiie de Chazelle', No. 25, near Mon ceaux Park.
The head of the new Colossus, *'Liberty," which is in future to light all nations into the harbor of New York,

Tho Colosanl Kliitne of Liberty New York Times October 0 Tho presence In Now York of tho French visitors to tho Yorktown celebration sug gests tho propriety of reminding tho Ameri can public of tho efforts which tho French nro making to keep alive- nnd pcrpctuato tho memory of tho disinterested friendship and generous aid given by Franco to tho colonics of North America in their strugglo for liberty nnd independence Sovcrnl years ago mi association was formed In Franco by somo of tbo most distinguished Eonubllcam with tlio titlo of Tho Franco- American Union under tho presidency of Americas special lrlcnii senator iiDouiago tho object of this association being to per notuato tho memory of tho friendship twecn Tranco nnd America by presenting to tho pcopl of tho United States a colossal statuo of Liborty to bo erected on Bedlbos Island in tho harbor of Now York
Public sentiment hbar been thorough ly aroused at last, ini favor of the move ment toward the erectingof Bartholdl's statute, "Liberty Enlightening the World," inu the harbor of New York.
This now Wonder of the World, which is now being loaded on the French transport lsere for shipment to this country, is tho largest statue in tho world.
The Bartholdi pedestal fund is nearly complete. The statue has arrived and soon New York harbor will be graced by the most magnificent colossal statue the world has ever seen.
The coloRwl statue of Liberty, so lons in pro? cess of ?section on Bedlow's Island, will be un veiled next Th?-day with all the pomp Rmi circumstance of a great National cerem ny.

and Scovel Richardson, member of the Board of Parole, U. S. Department of Justice; have given their support to help establish The Museum at the foot of the Statue of Liberty to dramatize the contributions im migrants have made to America.

Fare 5 cents each way! a boat trip over to the Statue of Liberty by way of Ellis Island, Gov ernors' Island. If you’re lucky like I am you might see the liners sailing in and out of New York Harbor. From about the middle of the foundation for the Statue we saw the Queen Mary put out to sea. She was a large, impressive looking liner but the fascination of the Statue sort of dulled the thrill of seeing England’s pride of the seas. Climbing into the crown of the Statue of Liberty is punishment that many patriotic Americans and ardent sightseers subject themselves to.
